reference.scope: VARIANTS CSID GLY-577; PRO-594; PRO-694; ASP-1073; TYR-1229; GLY-1367 AND CYS-1745

comment.text: Plays an important role in the final stage of carbohydrate digestion. Isomaltase activity is specific for both alpha-1,4- and alpha-1,6-oligosaccharides.
Hydrolysis of sucrose and maltose by an alpha-D-glucosidase-type action.
Hydrolysis of (1->6)-alpha-D-glucosidic linkages in some oligosaccharides produced from starch and glycogen by alpha-amylase, and in isomaltose.
The resulting sucrase and isomaltase subunits stay associated with one another in a complex by non-covalent linkages.
Expressed in the poorly differentiated crypt cells of the small intestine as well as in the mature villous cells. Expressed at very low levels in the colon.
The precursor is proteolytically cleaved when exposed to pancreatic proteases in the intestinal lumen.

disease.name: Congenital sucrase-isomaltase deficiency
disease.description: Autosomal recessive intestinal disorder that is clinically characterized by fermentative diarrhea, abdominal pain, and cramps upon ingestion of sugar. The symptoms are the consequence of absent or drastically reduced enzymatic activities of sucrase and isomaltase. The prevalence of CSID is 0.02 % in individuals of European descent and appears to be much higher in Greenland, Alaskan, and Canadian native people. CSID arises due to post-translational perturbations in the intracellular transport, polarized sorting, aberrant processing, and defective function of SI.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
There is a high degree of homology between the isomaltase and sucrase portions (41% of amino acid identity) indicating that this protein is evolved by partial gene duplication.
Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 31 family.

property.value: Congenital sucrase-isomaltase deficiency with minimal starch tolerance

feature.description: Helical; Signal-anchor for type II membrane protein
In CSID; missorting of the enzyme to the basolateral membrane; dbSNP:rs121912612.
In CSID; causes loss of anchored SI from the membrane; dbSNP:rs267607049.
In CSID; SI accumulates predominantly in the ER; dbSNP:rs121912613.
In CSID; exhibits intracellular accumulation of mannose-rich SI in the Golgi; dbSNP:rs121912611.
